'run' goes inside 'lifecycle' keyword
timeline.author: ShirleyZheng92
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -12,11 +12,32 @@ An important use-case for this property is when two clones of this config are di
 (no longer cross-updating).  Updates made while disconnected can be reconstructed by
 replaying each other's logs upon reconnection.  This "hack" depends on the two systems having sufficiently well synchronized clocks.
 
+## One way of visualizing it
+
+Given the following configuration in YAML format,
+
+```yaml
+main:
+    requires: myService

replies.bodyText: Yeah I realized that... But as a sample, any key and object could explain the idea so I didn't bother to change that. Thanks for pointing it out though!
replies.author: leaf94

replies.bodyText: @ShirleyZheng92  Strangely enough, "requires" was "dependencies" very early on.  But when there is only one dependency, it read awkwardly.  I nearly added a "dependency" keyword, but instead switched to "requires" because that doesn't have the singular/plural problem.
replies.author: JamesGosling

replies.bodyText:
Because of the singular/plural problem I updated 'dependencies' to take in list instead of single string:
dependencies:
  - serviceA
  - serviceB

Since we currently have serviceName:StartWhen, and potentially other attribute like 'hotpluggable' , keeping everything in a comma separated string can grow more confusing
replies.author: ShirleyZheng92

timeline.message: Change to absolute link for github to work
